story:
Hi, my name is Alice Vinson I am an artist and art professor. I have been creating and exhibiting mixed media artists books for twelve years, and installation and multimedia works for the past two. My work has been published in 500 Handmade Books Volumes I & II and is held in The University of Arizona Library Special Collection and The University of Arizona Poetry Center Permanent Collection. 

My current project, likeness of disposition, includes the taking of one Polaroid image per day and recording mundane information about the activities of the day with some notes about mood and physical feelings. (read more about the details of project here: likeness of disposition). The work is updated daily in an online virtual journal, a public exhibition of sorts, that anyone can view and participate in.


06.09.15


physical state: tired

mental state: content, sense of accomplishment

camera: SX-70 (folding)

image: rubber boots

time: 11:50 p.m.

weather: warm, clear



The project began last year, on Dec. 30th, 2014. It is an attempt to see if there is a correlation between one’s emotional and physical state and a random photograph recorded on a daily basis. In other words, is it possible that the tools and materials themselves are somehow able to reflect the mental and physical state that one might be in at the time one takes a photograph?



Three months after beginning likeness of disposition, I created a small book, which I offered for sale through my website.


 

likeness of disposition: 12.30.14 thru 01.17.15


I would like to create a year-long daily record for this project. I plan on exhibiting the final book along with a large hanging piece of the images quilted together between layers of clear vinyl. The images have evolved into a beautiful journal with layered meaning and potential, however, having recently finished graduate school, funds are short. In order to complete a 365-day investigation of interior reality accompanied by an exterior recording on polaroid film, I need your help to purchase supplies.


What I Need

$1,300.00 is what is needed in order to finish out the year.

Budget

  • 365 pieces of Polaroid instant film - $1150
  • 6 yards clear vinyl material for public exhibit piece - $60
  • Supplies for hanging piece and storage - $200
  • Photo paper and inks for digital prints - $400
  • 2 self published hardcover books (approx. 380 pgs. each) - $300

Some Of The Perks

Below you will find photographs of some of the perks offered. My art pieces have been shown in venues throughout the US and abroad including The University of Arizona Museum of Art, Arizona State University as well as locations in New York and the United Kingdom. Perks include archival prints, and several of my artists books. I am also offering hand made mixed media postcards and blank books too.

Mexico

 

soft

Previous to Past

 

Do Not Touch

 

ATypical Day


Other

Softcover Letterpress Notebooks - Please note that you choose this perk that you will receive a randomly selected notebook. The above image serves only as an example as to what you might receive. 

Leather Blank Books (Mini and Medium Sizes) -  Note: Leather cover and/or tie may vary slightly in color.


 

Another Way You Can Help

Any amount you can contribute will help—but if money is short, you can spread the word about the project. Forward my campaign information on to others via word of mouth, email, or the Indigogo share tools.


More Detailed Information About My Project

The Process:

  • Only one photograph is taken per day.
  • I randomly select one of six different Polaroid cameras. The cameras contain either black and white or color film, but I am never certain which camera contains what type of film.
  • The photograph is taken at a random time. I take a photograph as quickly as possible, trying to not think about subject matter or composition.
  • Once the photograph is taken I document the date, time, how I am feeling physically, how I am feeling mentally, general weather conditions, the camera used and any problems or malfunctions that may occur. I do this within the time it takes for the Polaroid image to develop.
  • The photograph is scanned and posted to the project blog, a.k.a. the virtual gallery, with no data given. I want viewers to comment on the image, reflecting what they think it represents on a physical and emotional level.
  • Data is given one week after the photograph is posted. The information appears under the original image post.

story:
Hi friends,
I am a recipient of the 2016 Escola Estudio Raizvanguarda Artist in Residence Program. This residency I'm embarking on is 2 months. This will be my 1st adventure overseas and I'm highly grateful of the conditions.
A bit about RAIZVANGUARDA
RAIZVANGUARDA was born from the desire of a small group of people who wanted to do more for art, taking as its starting point in the municipality of Góis. Their vision as an organization is to be a cultural leader in the region. To be Independent, with a sustainable structure and actively participate in public life.

The cost of the program is €680, which will cover housing and utilization of studio and performance spaces around town. What the tuition does not cover is food, traveling arrangements and paying dancers who will help bring my series of ideas to fruition.  What is also not supplied is studio rental outside of the organization.

A bit about myself.
I started classically training in dance at 14 under Florida Dance Theatre's Carol Erkes and FrediDance Project's Ferdinand DeJesus. The part I enjoyed the most about dance, and still to this day, was the process of creation. The small details expressed through the choreographer intrigued me deeply as I knew this was a message put forth to the audience. I extended my training in Philadelphia under Zane Booker, soon after enrolling in the LINES Ballet training program. My experience at LINES was a gateway into the depths of what a true artist is. This program helped infuse my art with gratitude and self respect.
Throughout time I've grown to understand my art and push it further, reaching for magical moments. RAIZVANGUARDA is the next step in facilitating these moments. This is an opportunity to make connections and collaborate with some amazing artists in Europe. This action has always been a dream of mine.

Soon following RAIZVANGUARDA I will take flight to San Francisco, re-connecting with Olivia Coombs, creating our 6th piece titled "Continued".  We always strive to think outside of our box, utilizing everyday props and giving normalcy a different perspective. This piece will be our best one yet! We as a duet will also step out of our known comfort by leading The LINES Ballet training program in a week workshop. We are so excited and would like to thank Karah Abiog for the opportunity.

So donate!! You can also show support by sharing with friends and family members  in and out of your community.

I thank you for your generosity.

story:
I began plein-air painting in the winter of 2016 and have become totally obsessed with the adventure of painting outside on location.  I am asking you to support this campaign to help Indianapolis become known as an "Artist's City." Indianapolis is a place where artists and collectors can thrive and orbit the same circles. Together we can eliminate the stigma of the "Starving Artist" by simply feeding the artist. Contributors will insure that this new adventure will bring an exciting vitality to the (already awesome) Indianapolis painting community. 

I will need roughly $5,000 for gas, vehicle maintenance, camping, food, painting supplies, framing and exhibition costs. These 60 limited western landscape paintings will be shown one night and available at half retail value to you! If I cannot reach my goal, I will still make the trip with funds that have been donated to offset my cost.

I am making this ambitious trip with high hopes that it will have a residual motivational effect on the Indianapolis painting community. My track record for success as a full-time working artist is fundamentally based on hard work and your reciprocating support. 

If you cannot contribute financially, please share and promote this project with your friends. 

 

Best,

Benny

 

SITE MAP:

story:
Finding Home on the Playa...

We at the Art To Be Continued Collective are bringing a 20' long interactive Centipede to the Playa and we need your help! We are scouting for volunteers to bring Myriapoda to life, but if you can’t make it out to help, Please consider donating to our campaign!

The project is lead by David Date, a self-described serial fabricator. New to the ATBC team is David Han, a visionary artist and futurist metal sculptor. With your help, we are bringing a fully autonomous mechanical organism to walk Playa!

Reinventing the Steam Engine to walk the Playa!

While studying steam engines, David Date discovered a mechanism which mimicked the kinematics of walking insects and became the inspiration for Myriapoda Robota.

In addition to help, we need to raise $15,000 to make this happen. Your contribution will afford us the Aluminum, electrical, lighting, and transportation service needed to bring Myriapoda to life!

In gratitude for your contribution, we have assembled a line of sculptural and renewable energy perks which harness the abundance of energy around us and will enable you to reduce your atmospheric MOOP!

Building on previous installations...

Myriapoda Robota first appeared at BRC 2016, as a 6 segment long centipede. Despite being over loaded with lead acid batteries and all steel construction, she walked!

That same year, Art To Be Continued received Honorarium to bring the 10 Benches of Sitting Man to Playa, a bench for each of the 10 principles. 

In 2017, we brought Kinetic MerKaBa Vehicle and received another Honorarium grant for the 11 Benches of Sitting Man. 

For 2018 I-Robot, we are bringing Myriapoda Robota and Mebot, A selfish robot bench made of antiquated technology sitting alone in his own splendor...

What could go wrong?

Our biggest concern in bringing Myriapoda to Playa is... Playa! Although Myriapoda’s walking mechanism only consists of 3 links, each link is floated on 3 thrust bearings. In all, Myriapoda will have over 150 bearings which will inevitably accumulate dust, and slowly build up friction. 

The two competing beliefs in how to deal with the Playa and mechanics are encasing the bearings in grease, or using no lube at all. We have devised a method of dry lubing roller surfaces, and sealing them with greased o-rings. This will capture Playa before it permeates the bearing surfaces!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even more than funds, we need help! We are looking for help with the fabrication, programming, electrical, and lighting!

We will also have a tax deductible donation channel set up through the Org if that interests you as well. 

If you cant do either, sign up for our mailing list and follow us on our journey to Playa!

With Gratitude,
Art To Be Continued Collective

story:
I was born and raised in Port-au-Prince Haiti. I am a licensed Social Worker in the District of Columbia and Maryland. I graduated from Howard University in DC with a Master’s Degree in Social Work. also, have a Master Degree in International Services from American University in Washington DC.

I have over 25 years of experience in a variety of Social Work settings and diverse clients such as schools, adoption/foster care, medical, behavior crisis intervention and geriatric. I also volunteer my time and experience by providing emotional support services as needed to the Haitian community of the Washington DC and Maryland area.

 Three of my great passions in life are travel, birds photography and collecting Haiti vintage postcards. I believe that my postcards collection has made me better appreciate my native country and culture as well as that of the people I’ve met through traveling.

My campaign is to raise $4,000 dollars for framing and reproducing the postcards for a small exhibition. The Exhibition is scheduled for May 2018 to celebrate Haitian Heritage.  May 18th is all about celebrating the culture and heritage of the Haitian flag, which is emblazoned with the country’s coat of arms and the colors red and blue, adopted from the French flag. Haiti gained its independence from France in 1804, making the first Black country in the world.

The name of the Exhibit is Haiti A History in Postcards.  Your contribution will greatly help me achieve my goal.  My vision is to take visitors on a visual journey through Haiti as it illustrates postcards as early 1900's. Other Haitians took to social media to share pictures of  Haiti's beautiful beaches to make a point about the President's alleged remarks. I decided to do a  postcard exhibition to highlight a positive view of Haitian culture, lifestyle, and history.

The exhibitions will feature about 200 vintage postcards reproduced from my private collections. The postcards are selected to retell the stories of Haiti hidden, not only in the recess of time but also a world misunderstand.  The exhibit will highlight sightseeings, transportations, streets scenes, daily livings, government buildings, commercials, churches, schools institutions, and park.  Medias, movies, and news always defined Haiti as in unattractive, poor, primitive, aggressive and complex island. My challenge is to raise enough money for ten 24X30 gallery frames at about $300 each to display 20  postcards each.  

Just in case I don't reach the entire goal, I will make do with what I have and still bring you the best show possible. Of course, the show would not reach its full potential if I don't hit the mark so, with your help, I am hoping for the best in hitting our target amount to make this show as spectacular as possible.  My hope is that on day non-Haitians will be inspired to travel and visit this forgotten and misunderstand Caribbean island.

Please spread the word about this campaign on social media or tex.  I am certain with your help, this will get me to reach my goal and beyond! Thank you so much and I am looking forward to doing this project with you!

Thank you so much for checking out my campaign page.

story:
Introduction:

Silwan is considered one of the most crowded towns in Palestine, where more than 60,000 people live in it. The neighborhood of Silwan is located in the southern part of the Old City of Jerusalem. It is considered one of the most marginalized and alienated areas in Palestine, facing constant threats and attacks directed by the Israeli government and settlers. Such threats include: arrests of children, youth, and women as well as seizure of buildings by Israeli settlers, demolition of houses and forced evacuation.

We believe that such threats and attacks attempt to displace original citizens and evacuate the area from its Palestinian residents who own the land, particularly due to the Israeli government and settlers’ claim that Silwan area is the capital of The Kingdom of David, hence they claim their right to control the land.

In fact, the suffering of Silwan and Jerusalem areas is tremendous; they live under continuous risks of losing their homes. “Palestinians are rarely able to obtain building permits; Israeli authorities approve less than two percent of requests. An estimated 60,000 Palestinians are at risk of having their homes demolished in occupied East Jerusalem, while another 43,000 housing units are needed to address the housing shortage.

According to UN report of 2016 “hundreds of families are at risk of forcible transfer in East Jerusalem owing to the seizure of numerous buildings by Israeli settlers in Silwan and in the Old City, as well as by the development of various parks throughout East Jerusalem. These facts suggest that there is a close link between the rate of demolitions and forcible evictions and settlement expansion

Project description:

The overall objective of the project is to enhance the Arts School of Silwan and empower it administratively and financially in order to be able to conduct activities and service under the tough political conditions in Silwan. It contributes to achieving the following objectives: 

  1. Spread cultural awareness among the community of Silwan
  2. Provide equal opportunity and accessibility for children and youth in Silwan to learn arts regardless of their economic situation. 
  3. Provide safe environment for children and youth to be able to develop their artistic skills which will be reflected on their personality and behavior.
  4. Contribute to the enhancement of art education in Palestinian schools through promoting arts to school students and introducing them the different types of arts and its role in building strong communities.
  5. Promote the Arabic cultural identity of Silwan in specific and Jerusalem in general through enhancing the role of youth and local community in preserving cultural heritage.
  6. Establish and enhance partnerships with local community organizations and arts centers in Silwan and other areas in Jerusalem.
  7. Enhance and enrich the cultural and artistic life in Silwan and Jerusalem in order to enhance exchange with other cultures.
  8. Spread love and peace and joy in Jerusalem within the concept of resistant and resilient community.

Target Group (Annual numbers):

Category

Male

Female

Children and youth of Silwan in particular and of Jerusalem in specific (Age: 7-20) 

880

880

Residents of Silwan and Jerusalem targeted as primarily staff of the Forum.

8

6

Local community of Silwan and Jerusalem

10,000

10,000

 

Expected Results:

  1. The first vocational arts school in Silwan is empowered and enhanced.
  2. Around 170 students (4- 18 years, 50 % female), regardless of their economic situation, are annually enrolled in the Arts school and have received free education in different arts fields such as music, singing, drama, theater and Dabkeh.
  3. 30 music and artistic educational concerts are organized targeting around 1,500 students (50% female) in Palestinian governmental schools in Jerusalem. Such educational concerts promote arts and non-curricular events through spreading awareness of the importance of arts as a tool of developing youth’s personality.
  4. 3 music choirs are established and approximately 90 male and female students aged between 8 and 14 are being trained on a weekly bases. These choirs aim at promoting the Palestinian musical heritage and Arabic music, besides enhancing the unity among children of Silwan via the social and cultural connections between them.
  5. 10 artistic events are organized targeting Silwan and Jerusalem community in order to reach approximately 20,000 people (50% are females).
  6. Two summer camps are organized reaching approximately 120 children aged between 7 and 18.
  7. In collaboration with specialized arts schools and academies, scholarships are provided for talented children and youth in order for them to pursuit education in arts and music.
  8. Children and youth of Silwan are connected and linked up through culture and arts.
  9. The Arabic cultural identity of Silwan is preserved and promoted through the support of children and youth as main key actors of resistance. Local community’s awareness about Arts and culture is enhanced.

story:
By supporting LIVING AWAY / A WAY OF LEAVING you will have the opportunity to contribute to the visibility of migrant Cuban artists in NYC with unique but often marginalized artistic languages.

We strongly believe that there is a need for more alternative and inclusive art projects in NYC, especially those that empower the voices of migrants, as LIVING AWAY / A WAY OF LEAVING intends to do. We believe that in the current circumstances this project should not only be possible but necessary.

We are an experienced team that has developed various initiatives to support emerging independent artist. We always believed in collaborative networks as the base for developing platforms as such. With the support of these bases we were able to nurture a vibrant movement of performing artist in Cuba and internationally.

We launched this campaign with the goal of achieving a basic budget that will make possible this unique event in New York City. With your contribution you will be helping towards the development of a community of migrant artist and have a strong impact in the cultural landscape of the city.

All the participant artists will generously present their work without monetary compensation. But we still need a basic budget to cover technical, travel and production expenses. YOUR CONTRIBUTION WILL BE ESSENTIAL FOR MAKING THIS DREAM COME TRUE!

All contributors will get access to the full program of performances and our infinite gratitude. . For larger contributions you will be included as sponsor, a special package of the printed material and other items listed in our perks.

We are trying to raise 7000 dollars that will be destined to cover the space, board, lodging and travel expenses of the participant artists. If we reach our goal, we will be able to pay a small stipend to our production team and produce a special catalog with the documentation of the event.

With LIVING AWAY / A WAY OF LEAVING we want to tackle the difficulty of creating alternative performing arts projects in the city of New York. While being such a multicultural metropolis, the creation of more spaces that allow dialogue among other cultures is still necessary.

We believe not only that we will be able to attract the attention of a wide audience with our strong and diverse performance program, but also that we will situate a community of unique artists on NYC's map.

HELP US IN ANY WAY YOU CAN, with a contribution and by sharing this campaign with as many people you can. You can easily share it by using the share tools provided by Indiegogo!

story:
WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT:

Hi! I am Semra Sevin, my background is in fashion & art photography and I am the initiator and curator behind the exhibition “Passengers of a Kaleidoscopic Journey”.  I need to raise 5,000 euros to cover the costs and would love your support.  I need to find funding for transportation costs of work from both Istanbul and LA, insurance, technical support, lighting, payment for the exhibition space.  Every penny you kindly donate will take us one step closer to realizing our goal.  

To keep costs low and within a tight budget, I am relying on the support of volunteers and so your funds will go directly to the cost of installing the exhibition.  

To attract as many members of the public as possible the exhibition is free of charge.  In addition, to maximise the exhibition’s exposure it coincides with the makers of "The Haus" http://www.thehaus.de/ .

WHY I BELIEVE THE THEME OF IDENTITY IS AN IMPORTANT ISSUE TO DISCUSS:

We all face challenges in regards to our identity.  From my own firsthand experience, as a daughter of immigrants who moved to Germany, I know how others have perceived me to fit their ideas of a cultural norm.  My perceived (!) identity has fluctuated from German to Turkish, from a fundamentalist to a parasite.  When I read or watch media reports about either mass migration due to war or economic deprivation or about individual discrimination due to gender or race, I feel we are still only at the start of the debate on identity.  

Last year, I received a public commission to photograph and interview immigrant’s children between LA and Berlin.  It exposed me to how increasingly cosmopolitan the world is becoming but, perhaps not always diverse, and I mean diversity in the acceptance of culture, race and gender.  My own interpretation of identity through my photography is to explore variety and to celebrate it. 

By collaborating with my fellow artists, I hope the exhibition will inspire people to bring cultures together, to accept others for who they are and to create a positive network between artists from different backgrounds. Through our passion for art, I believe we can start the debate on questioning concepts of identity as well as challenging prejudices. 

If you agree, put on your sponsoring outfit to support Passengers of a Kaleidoscopic Journey!  I look forward to your support.
story_txt:
WHY WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT:
Hi! I am Semra Sevin, my background is in fashion & art photography and I am the initiator and curator behind the exhibition “Passengers of a Kaleidoscopic Journey”.  I need to raise 5,000 euros to cover the costs and would love your support.  I need to find funding for transportation costs of work from both Istanbul and LA, insurance, technical support, lighting, payment for the exhibition space.  Every penny you kindly donate will take us one step closer to realizing our goal.  
To keep costs low and within a tight budget, I am relying on the support of volunteers and so your funds will go directly to the cost of installing the exhibition.  
To attract as many members of the public as possible the exhibition is free of charge.  In addition, to maximise the exhibition’s exposure it coincides with the makers of "The Haus" http://www.thehaus.de/ .

story:
My story – the short version

I’m Sofia, an artist and illustrator since 15+ years. I started handpoke tattooing 2 years ago and since then, I have received a lot of feedback from the people I've tattooed on how safe and seen they feel with me, and how they appreciate my bringing heart and soul into the process.

Here’s what one of my tattooees, Uma, says about me:

Sofia is the most gentle, powerful and sweet tattoo artist. She meets you with such warmth, understanding and professionalism. It is impossible to not feel safe and understood when she is tattooing you. She is not only a great artist, she also brings magic in to her work and the whole experience becomes something bigger than “just” a tattoo, where something profoundly soul connected can take place.

The reason why I want to open my own studio is that I have never felt at home in "regular" tattoo studios in cities and the atmosphere that I have felt there. I want to do Soul work, making body art that is a visual reminder of one's inner truth.

So in order to continue on this art/soul/heart path, I am creating my own tattoo studio where I get to set the tone! And I'm building it in nature. In a tipi. This one:

 

 

The studio

I lived in this tipi last summer. It's an amazing space, 20' wide (6 meters) with a very light and calm atmosphere on the inside. One can feel the elements in there – the wind, the earth and the raindrops drumming on the canvas.

And why a tattoo studio in a tipi? Because it goes hand in hand with the way that I tattoo, by hand, in reverence of life and nature. And because I have the perfect spot for it; a place where people come to celebrate heart and spirit – the course center of Ängsbacka in Sweden. 

Creating a tattoo studio out of a tipi means turning an already magical and beautiful space into also being a functional and hygienic space. It means to build a proper floor, getting running hot water, buying furniture, sewing new inner walls, making it rain drop safe, paying for permits … and much more. (See below for more details about where the money will go.)

Pachamama Handpoke Tattoo (that's the name) will be open during the Ängsbacka summer festival season, June through August – hopefully for many summers to come! The opening date is June 10th this year.

If you don't know about Ängsbacka, it is Sweden's biggest course center for spiritual and personal growth, as well as a live-in community. It's awesome. Learn more about it here: https://angsbacka.se/

 

Why support this project?

Because it will be a place for soul, heart, connection and slowness in a fast-paced world, and we need those kind of places. I receive so much feedback from other people that confirms this. The studio will be a beautiful and magic oasis that you can come and visit in the summer, going through the ritual of getting a tattoo or not – or you can help create the opportunity for other people to come and do the same.

What I need and what you get

I need an energy boost from as many people as possible to fuel me in building this space! The energy boost can come in different shapes: showing me your support & your belief in me, sharing this campaign with people that you know, and/or donating money.

I'm aiming for €3500 altogether, and within that amount, even the smallest donation counts! With your help and support + my vision and creative skills, we'll create magic.

Find a perk option that delights you and press go - - - >

Please share. 

How will I use the money?

- Flooring: laminate wooden floor €300, paint & tools for the floor mandala painting €100

- Water systems: water heater €200, basin €150, mirror €50, paper towel dispenser €30,  dampness protection for flooring and walls €50, soap and desinfection lotion €40

- Furniture: Massage bench €150, desk €50, a few cupboards €200, two stools €100, two room dividers €200, separate storage for shoes €70, two doormats (inside + outside) €60

- The tipi: textile for making waterproof and un-stainable inner walls: €300, new rope for putting up inner walls €50, rain drop protection system €100

- Hygiene: course to get a tattoo hygiene certificate: €200, fee for checking the studio hygiene (done by the Swedish hygiene authorities Miljö&Hälsa): €400

- Containers: for clean/used tattoo material and clothing, indoor/outdoor containers, for garbage etc: €250 

- Cleaning materials and storage for them: €100

- Tattoo equipment such as needles, ink, gloves, stencils, ink cups, vaseline: €400

Risks & challenges

In any art/design project, things can go wrong, be delayed, mess up... I am used to those situations since I have 15 years of experience in making art projects. Therefore, I don't panic when things take longer, and I have a certain wait-and-see attitude when it comes to solving problems. Sometimes 'problems' get solved by not doing anything at all! Other times 'easy' details turn out to take forever. The worst scenario I can imagine for this project is that the opening date gets delayed, but apart from that, I'm pretty sure I can work my way through the challenges that show up.

If I don't reach my entire funding goal, I would still do my best to make the studio happen with what I have, even if that means to live on oatmeal! I will keep funders updated in the process, posting pictures and anecdotes of how I build, fix, paint and manifest my way forward.

 

 

A note on handpoke tattooing

There are some differences between a handpoked tattoo and a machine-made tattoo. The process of making a handpoked tattoo is quieter, less painful and takes longer. I hold the tattoo needle in my hand like a pen, I dip it in ink, and I create the image dot by dot. The needle/ink reaches the same skin depth as in a 'regular' tattoo, but the handpoked tattoo generally never bleeds since the skin gets less traumatized. (It's under less of an attack compared to a tattoo done by machine that might use more needles, and go much faster.) Because it takes longer to create a handpoked tattoo, it works best for making smaller pieces, and is not a good method if you want a big sleeve/leg/entire back, since that would take literally forever. The price for a certain sized handpoked tattoo may be higher than the 'same' tattoo made by machine, and that has to do with the amount of time that it takes to make it. The handpoke method is for someone who would enjoy a quiet, heartfelt tattoo session and a not-so-big tattoo that is like a piece of jewellery.

 

 

MY STORY part I:

How I Found Creativity Again

This crowdfunding campaign is actually a part of my journey of finding creative flow. It started in a basement studio in Malmö in 2015, at a time when I was feeling completely blocked. One lucky day, I quit (well, put on hold) what I was doing – working as a freelance illustrator – and went traveling, exploring things that brought me joy: nature, spirituality and community.

On my path, people inspired me in so many ways, one of which was the suggestion to get a handpoke tattoo kit together with my friend Uma. I wasn't very interested in tattooing and had never thought about handpoke tattooing before, but I said yes only because I wanted to spend more time with her! Though before I knew it, I’d ordered more material and was practicing on fruits, my toes, my thighs and fellow community members…

Thanks to the community where I was living, Ängsbacka, and thanks to my travels thereafter, I've had an abundance of people to practice on. Thanks to letting the people who crossed paths with me inspire me with new ideas, my creative inspiration came back. I started combining the collaborative act of tattooing with my interests in plants, animals and shamanism. People would share their stories and dreams with me, and together we would weave images for them.

Reaching out and asking for your support is a way for me to continue on the path of collaboration. It feels vulnerable to do it, but I know that there's a chance of greater magic in my creative work when I do it together with others, in one way or another.

 

 

MY STORY part II:

Tattoo history vs. What I used to think about tattoos 

As I grew up, I was taught that ”if I ever want a proper job, I shouldn’t get a tattoo”. So to be on the safe side and keep doors open between me and the imaginary future high-end job, I didn't get any tattoos...

...until many years later, when I surprisingly found myself tattooing my own toes, and other people's arms and fingers. It was a paradoxical situation because while I was having fun, I was (in some off-grid space in my mind) also potentially ruining the chance for us all to land those important jobs!

Obviously, I needed to shake these beliefs off if I were to continue tattooing, so I started researching into tattoo history. I found Lars Krutak, a tattoo anthropologist who made me see the immense range of meaning that tattoos have had in history. It has meant everything from spiritual to criminal, aristocrat-ey to trendy, medicinal to mafia… found on Ötzi the ice man, Mayan princesses, Eskimoes and other indigenous peoples and on British upperclass ladies of the Victorian era. 

Thanks to Lars Krutak, my belief system could finally free itself from the limiting idea of what tattooing ”means” in modern times. I decided that it will mean whatever I want it to mean, and there’s no right or wrong way to wear it.

And by the time I decided for this to be my job, the 'proper job' issue was solved.

 

 

MY STORY part III:

Divinity & ceremony

The way I think of tattoos is this: our bodies and our skin is sacred. They are gifts that we get to keep for a 100 years or so. We often take them for granted, but they're actually miracles. When I tattoo somebody, together we take a piece of that person’s soul and put it on the outside, made visible. It makes me think of life and death and what skin is and what life is...

And at the same time, from the perspective of how old the galaxies are, the human physical body is just a blink of an eye, and therefore, getting a tattoo is not that big of a deal. The body lives and then it dies. If I tattoo something on myself today and regret it when I’m 99, so what? I see it as a diary on the skin. It’s also a self-love school, to accept oneself in all stages of life.

With tattooing, I try to use my artistic skills to see people, to lift them up, into their dreams and hopes and potential.

<3

I hope to see you in the summer and that you will want to join me in creating this project! It’s gonna be magic. 

With love, Sofia

Contact

Email: lindholm.sofia@gmail.com

Skype: sofia.lindholm

www.sofialindholm.com

www.instagram.com/sofia.lindholm

www.facebook.com/sofia.lindholm.773

 

How to book a tattoo with me

Are you selecting a perk that means that you (or someone you know) will get a tattoo from me this summer? Please get in touch for scheduling an appointment by emailing me at lindholm.sofia@gmail.com

We would start by schedule a 20 min Skype call to talk about your idea, and then schedule the actual tattoo appointment.

story:
"Songs of Story Men" goes Global! 

Hello Everyone!

We are Vaneshran Arumugam and Emmanuel Castis - the Story Men - and our show is an unconventional offering of decades of experience as performers, musicians, close friends and storytellers. It presents a performance that defies categorisation, blurring lines between styles genres, formats and cultures, inviting dialogue and introspection in an experience not to be missed.

Said of Songs of Story Men:

"...the two performers and their trusty guitars venture through a range of musical styles from jazz and reggae to folk and classical ,  using well-known musics along with their own compositions. The music interspersed with running dialogue and reflective soliloquy delivers a journey into story and a contemplation of how songs and music hold our deepest emotions, while still compelling the audiences to clap along with joy..."

Songs of Story Men has been invited to headline the fourth instalment of St Francis College's Moral Sense Colloquium in the heart of New York City's historical Brooklyn Heights.  In addition we have been invited to perform at Mercy College by special arrangement with the Program Head of Health Sciences.

These performances form part of our long professional commitment to bringing South African work and stories to the world and fostering meaningful relationships for collaboration and exchange of knowledge and expertise. We believe our (South African) work is of the highest standard fit to have a powerful and lasting impact on any platform in the world.  Our hope is also that these prestigious invitations will help us build momentum and help us market the show for performances elsewhere, particularly in South Africa and the rest of Africa where the focus of demand tends to be on the US and Europe. This show encourages audiences to challenge their perceptions and to embrace community and is part of realising our deep mission to use the Arts and Creativity and Imagination to heal and inspire healing and well-being, and the success of this first international outing of the show will go far toward us developing and taking the show to more and more audiences both in South Africa and abroad

 

We are independent Artists with a Big Vision!

We are nearly all set to embark on this initial and important trip which will continue to take us on our journey toward making our dreams for this project real. Having made miracles happen to afford the travel and production costs, the last piece of our puzzle is Accomodation and Logistics while we are in New York. We have calculated that we need approximately USD 1500 to afford decent accommodation for the 15 days we are in New York and to ensure that we can get around efficiently from engagement to engagement. Whatever we raise will go toward these costs and anything in excess will go toward creating another performance opportunity for Songs of Story Men (either in New York or upon our return to SA and likely with an audience that would otherwise not afford the show)

"Songs of Story Men is the best thing I've seen at the festival"

We are confident that the work is of the highest calibre and comes with all our experience and skill as well as our honed intentions to use our Art to make the world a better place. We feel that this work  attempts to fill the widening gap between what we find in the world and the media and what we are really looking for. We see the success of this venture as a huge victory for Independent performing Artists, particularly South Africans, and an inspiration to others and ourselves to continue in this way and even take more risks in favour of producing original, compelling and necessary work and stories for audiences within and beyond traditional theatre walls!

Risks & Challenges

We have faced many so far and understand much of the complexity and difficulty of what we are trying to do, however we believe that our success will create advantages that far outweigh those risks and challenges, making every bit of effort worthwhile. We see Songs of Story Men as the beginning of a brand and a journey that has the potential to be as epic and far-reaching as our imaginations are, setting a trend and even creating a storytelling technique of its own - which every contributor will have claim to helping get off the ground!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to contribute money your help will be invaluable in getting the word out and helping us make some noise about our campaign and what we are hoping to achieve in New York with your assistance. 

  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank You and look forward to sharing the successes of this trip!

Whatever we raise will go toward these costs and anything in excess will go toward creating another performance opportunity for Songs of Story Men (either in New York or upon our return to SA and likely with an audience that would otherwise not afford the show)

"Songs of Story Men is the best thing I've seen at the festival"
We are confident that the work is of the highest calibre and comes with all our experience and skill as well as our honed intentions to use our Art to make the world a better place. We feel that this work  attempts to fill the widening gap between what we find in the world and the media and what we are really looking for. We see the success of this venture as a huge victory for Independent performing Artists, particularly South Africans, and an inspiration to others and ourselves to continue in this way and even take more risks in favour of producing original, compelling and necessary work and stories for audiences within and beyond traditional theatre walls!

Risks & Challenges
We have faced many so far and understand much of the complexity and difficulty of what we are trying to do, however we believe that our success will create advantages that far outweigh those risks and challenges, making every bit of effort worthwhile. We see Songs of Story Men as the beginning of a brand and a journey that has the potential to be as epic and far-reaching as our imaginations are, setting a trend and even creating a storytelling technique of its own - which every contributor will have claim to helping get off the ground!

Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you are unable to contribute money your help will be invaluable in getting the word out and helping us make some noise about our campaign and what we are hoping to achieve in New York with your assistance. 
Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
Thank You and look forward to sharing the successes of this trip!

story:
From the creator of NukeTheHamptons.com  and The Hamptons Dictionary  comes a brand new experience:

etherbay.co is a parody auction website where all the things you can't get on eBay are for sale - but only with cryptocurrency.

 

 

Among the many ideas for auction items are:

  • the missing CIA Oswald Folder
  • Senator Mitch McConnell
  • a First Edition Bible signed by God
  • Jeffery Epstein Celebrity Videos
  • the Formula for New Coke
  • Jeff Koon's Balloon Dog Orange
  • Outtakes from Stanley Kubrik's Fake Moon Landing Film
  • Seth Rich’s Thumb Drive
  • the Ark of the Covenant

 

Looking for more information about an item?  Read the detailed description on the item's auction page. Do you want to know who is bidding?  Click on the Bidder List to see all the current bidders and their bids.

 

 

As a work of conceptual art etherbay.co will be free for everyone to visit. There will be no advertising or other revenue generation - indeed, as a parody of commerce the inclusion of such crass commercialism would compromise the integrity of the concept (not to mention the aesthetics).

Thus this campaign, where I'm seeking your support for the creation of this project. But funding is not the only thing I'm looking for: ideas for content and co-conspirators are welcome, too. If you have an idea for an auction item or think you have what it takes to be a content creator, please contact me. Contributors will be fully credited.

Thank you,

Miles Jaffe
www.milesjaffe.com

 

for reference: Page Six and an image from nukethehamptons.com (retired 2011):

Refund Policy: Refunds are available prior to shipment. All sales are final upon shipment.

story:
Blukis dragging is an ancient community ritual in the Baltic States. People from small towns and villages used to drag Blukis or tree stump during the darkest night of the year, believing that visiting each home of their community members, they would gather all of the bad things, negative emotions, disputes and anger.
After the completing the ritual dragging of the Blukis, the community would burn the stump together and believed that this was a way to renew from the problems from the last year
The stump was seen as a symbol of a mystic underground being, sometimes a devil,that had hidden the sun from the people. Burning the Blukis down was believed to free the new sun, which is born in fire and thereby start a new cycle for the people.
Blukis in year 2011 was the first official Lithuanian theme camp. The stump ritual was dragged all over the Atlantic Ocean to the Nevada desert and presented as art concept for the Rites of Passage theme. Blukis camp was an interactive space for participants to relax and the Blukis on wheels was dragged all over the Black Rock City, visiting Theme Camps, playing and interacting with the participants, presenting the ritual and also gathering various evil energies. Though the stump of Blukis wasn‘t burned.
In Burning Man Fertility 2.0 Blukis, with the help of Czech burners will come to the Playa for a second time, this time as a CORE Project. It will be a giant tree stump sculpture with carvings of mystical runes&symbols illuminated by light emanating from inside the sculpture. The Blukis will be burned ceremoniously with the other 33 CORE effigies from around the world.

story:
In February 2011 a group of American,Canadian and Australian artist began documenting the experiences of service members going through stateside medical treatment.  Working primarily at in-patient surgical shock trauma wards, these artists spend time with some of the most physically battle damaged soldiers, sailors and Marines.  Many subjects of the artwork are patients mere weeks away from being injured in IED blasts and firefights in Afghanistan.  Most have endured multiple traumatic amputation injuries and disfiguring facial wounds, and will endure months of operations and challenging physical therapy.  With them on this journey back to wholeness are often equally traumatized family members.  All have volunteered to be sketched.

The Joe Bonham Project is named after the primary character in author Dalton Trumbo's WWI novel Johnny Got His Gun.  Based on a newspaper account of a visit by England's Prince of Wales to a profoundly injured Canadian soldier, Trumbo's fiction follows the unfolding existential nightmare of American doughboy Joe Bonham as he comes to realize the extent of his wounds.  Hit by an artillery blast, Bonham has lost all his limbs and his face.  Eventually he comes to terms with his condition and requests to be toured around the world in a glass box for all to see the reality of war.

Trumbo's Joe Bonham is tragically relegated to a life of forgotten isolation. As the Global War on Terror goes into its second decade, many service members are surviving the most catastrophic wounds imaginable.  Yet even as medical science continues to rise to address ever more devestating injuries, our nation seems to want to forget a new generation of Joe Bonhams.

Several of The Joe Bonham Project artists are seasoned war artists.  Michael Fay, Richard Johnson, Kristopher J. Battles, Steve Mumford, Victor Juhasz, Roman Genn and Robert Bates have each embedded with US combat units in both Iraq and Afghanistan in order to create art. Others, like Jeffrey Fisher, Fred Harper, Jess Ruliffson, Ray Alma, Bill Harris, Amber Martin and Josh Korenblat, have friends and family who have, or are currently serving in the armed forces.

All of The Joe Bonham Project artists are united in the mission to insure, through art, that we will not have another generation of forgotten, overlooked and marginalized Joe Bonhams.  Mike Fay has penned a series of articles for the New York Times, Richard Johnson has been featured in Canada's National Post and Victor Juhasz has posted at Drawger.  The Joe Bonham art and artists have been featured on CBS News, American Public Media's The Story with Dick Gordon and on page one of The New York Times Sunday Arts and Leisure section.

The Joe Bonham Project is the artistic partner of the musical video project called Still in the Fight.

Our first comprehensive exhibit at the Pepco Edison Place Gallery this November requires funds for a catalog, opening, panel discusion, movie screening, matting and framing of artwork and expenses for artists and panelist.  Sitting directly across the street from The National Portrait Gallery in our Nation's capital, this gallery offers us a unique opportunity to put Joe Bonham in front of the world.  Join us with your generous donations.

story:
Global Fiesta is a planned 11' by 64' mural on a wall facing the Stop and Shop parking lot at the Park Town Center complex on Raritan Ave.

Celebrate the cultural diversity of Highland Park

Exploring feelings we share through the common human experience, Global Fiesta highlights the musical nature of human beings. There can never be a party without music, so this mural expresses a universal language by exploring rhythm and movement through color and form. This mural shows all types of people just letting loose, because as people dance, all is forgotten and we unite as one. When people feel what unites us, they forget about differences and embrace similarities.

Unite through art

Different figures represent bodies in action and movement, tied together to reflect the common thread that binds humanity. Particular color combinations and ambiguous imagery hint at various different cultures. Rather than represent a dominant language, and alienate those who don't speak that language, the painting speaks to everyone through lines that simply allude to certain scripts. Everyone can read this painting the same way and understand its message.

Appreciate the significance

Kids will relate to the vibrant colors and identifiable figures, adults will embrace the deliberate composition and aesthetic qualities, while the artsy intellectuals will appreciate the strong theoretical foundation informed by a semiotic exploration of the universal human experience through the Apollinian and Dionysian duality. This mural will add a great amount of cultural capital to the town.

Meet the artists

My name is Jonathan Horowitz, Highland Park based artist and founder of PAZ culture system. You may have seen me covered in paint, putting finishing touches on my downtown murals, maybe you met me at the PAZ culture system organized Winter Art Bazaar, or perhaps I've even tutored your children, or you.

I was raised in Highland Park and I live here now. I want to show what makes Highland Park so great, translating our energy into substantial public art projects. This will be the first of many public art projects and part of the bigger campaign to transform downtown Highland Park as outlined in the Highland Park Redevelopment plan. This comprehensive document emphasizes the importance of public art and explains how it can translate into real economic gains for the town. 

I will be hiring and training other local artists so that they will be able to execute murals in the future. Basically, this mural provides a great opportunity to introduce new artists to public art in Highland Park and get them ready to help us show why our town is so great. We want to involve the public in our campaign so everyone can be part of this project.

Help us make this happen

The mural should take approximately 3-4 weeks. We will begin in late March or early April and be done in time for the annual Street Fair in May.

We will execute sixteen panels. Each panel should take approximately 20hrs. Each panel is approximately 44 sq/ft and we estimate that each square foot should take at least a half hour. This adds up to around 320hrs.

  • The mural will require three layers of paint. One layer to prime, one base coat, and one final layer.

  • We will be hiring 2 or 3 local artists and paying them a competitive rate 

In addition to these costs we have various other costs to address:

  • Conceptual sketch: 4 hrs
  • Scaled drawing: 8 hrs
  • Final scaled drawings and blueprint: 8 hrs
  • Marketing, Promotion, and Press: 8 hrs

We will need various funds for supplies such as paints, primer, ladders, brushes, and to pay for the various perks. If there are any funds left over, these will be used for future projects. 

Make an impact

Highland Park has the resources to transform the public sphere through public art. We can make it happen. Public art stimulates interest and helps the local economy. It will brighten the town and let people see the type of artistic resources that Highland Park has to offer. 

This is the start of something bigger.

We are promoting this mural heavily and we will get press coverage. People from other towns will want to come to Highland Park to see what all the buzz is about. Highland Park is a wonderfully diverse town with an abundance of artistic and intellectual energy! We have the resources and we need to use them.

Don't hesitate to share this link!

We will also be having a reception and art opening to celebrate the completion of this mural. The mural will be started in the end of March and finished just in time for the annual Street Fair in May.

Additional Comments:

This is a preliminary, conceptual sketch. Since most people won’t be seeing this close-up, and parts of the wall are obscured by greenery, detail may be lost, so large, solid, complementary colored shapes are applied to enable easy long distance viewing.The final sketch will have more effective color choices while the movements of the figures will be tighter and more expressive. The design may be simplified slightly in order to accommodate the limited resources available to execute this large endeavor. Also, some of the imagery or symbolism will be slightly adjusted so that the overall message is more cohesive and coherent. 

Send any questions to Jon@PAZculturesystem.com

story:
Summary

Sacrificial Poets is trying to send 6 of NC's top youth poets to the Brave New Voices (BNV) International Poetry Festival in San Francisco California this summer. BNV is an educational, empowering, and transformative week-long experience that will help our youth become better poets, mentors, and community leaders. 

$2,000 Will Cover: 

  • Festival Registration Fee
  • Housing at UC Berkeley for 1 week 
  • 2 meals for the team every day  
  • Spoken Word workshops for youth taught by world-class professionals 
  • Organizational Development workshops for mentors 
  • Performances and Events with top slam poets in the nation
  • Airfare for the coach 
  • Festival pass for chaperone  

 

How You Can Help 

Invest: Contribute online today. With your support, we can make this amazing experience possible for our youth! 

Invite: Help us spread the word about the campaign. Welcome your friends, family, and co-workers to become investors in this cause.  

Champion: Become an active member of our community. Come to events, support youth, and tell your own story. Help us advocate for the importance of arts education, emotional literacy, youth empowerment, and the transformative power of storytelling.


Who are the Sacrificial Poets?

The Sacrificial Poets’ mission is to inspire, foster, and promote artistic expression, personal growth, and social justice for youth in our collective communities through the use of the spoken and written word.

Sac Poe utilizes our unique "humanizing pedagogy" to engage young people in workshops, events, and mentorship across the Chapel Hill, Carrboro, and Durham area.

Our organization seeks to develop and foster young people’s capacity in creative writing, public speaking, emotional literacy, and civic engagement. We use the transformative power of storytelling and each individual’s voice to help build stronger communities.

For more information check out our Website!

 

What is Brave New Voices?

Every year in July, 50 teams of youth aged 13-19 come from all across the nation and world to participate in the Brave New Voices International Youth Poetry Slam Festival (BNV). During the week-long festival, which is held in a different U.S. city each year, these youth from Brooklyn to L.A., Hawaii to India, share space on and off the stage, forming powerful bonds of friendship and understanding through the expression of their words and art. They also participate in hands-on workshops with some of the world’s most renowned spoken word poets and performing artists.

Beginning in 2008, the Sacrificial Poets has taken a team of the top local youth poets to experience what is truly one of the most transformative experiences available to young writers and performers today. Upon returning home, these youth have gone on to become powerful leaders in our communities, creating poetry clubs, organizing inter-school competitions, hosting events, and even competing at the adult level in the National Poetry Slam as members of Durham’s Bull City Slam Team. In fact, graduates of the Sacrificial Poets youth slam team have performed at the Sundance Film Festival, featured at the Nuyorican Poets Café in Manhattan’s Lower East Side, and become teachers of poetry to youth across the state and nation.

For more information check out the BNV Website.

story:
Our Story

The Brandeis University Poetry Slam Team has competed at CUPSI (College Unions Poetry Slam Invitational) for the past three years.


This year, Usman Hameedi '12, Kass Levy '12, Jessica Hood '15, Malika Imhotep (Ra) '15, and Emily Duggan '15 are excited about representing Brandeis at this event. 


We need to raise enough money to meet our expenses. Unfortunately, nothing about this is cheap, and we are hoping that you can help!

 

The Impact

Your contribution will ensure that the poets attending this event will have the opportunity to give back to the Brandeis community. They will hear stories and have experiences that will galvanize their leadership potential. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

The money we earn is going directly to our expenses (travel, food, hotel) for CUPSI. 


If you've read this far, we already send our deepest gratitude. If you do decide to donate, here's some other ways we'd like to thank you:


Donate $20 or more and you'll get a personalized thank-you from the team.


$35 or more and you'll get a signed chapbook of poems from the team and vegan cookies!


$75 or more and you'll get a personal thank you, a signed chapbook, as well as a personalized poem written by the team. And yes, vegan cookies

$35 or more and you'll get a signed chapbook of poems from the team and vegan cookies!

$75 or more and you'll get a personal thank you, a signed chapbook, as well as a personalized poem written by the team. And yes, vegan cookies

story:
Short Summary

“Prophecy” is a collaborative effort by Corpus Christi artists Day Wheeler and Jimmy Peña born out of the thought that according to the Mayans, the year 2012 is predicted to be the end of the world. If mankind is still here in January 2013, this show will be a response to the genesis of a new apocalypse, which according to some, we may be witnessing now as our environment shows signs of deterioration and stress. 

"Prophecy" is a visual comment on the slow decline of the ecological balance of the Texas Gulf Coast as a result of petroleum waste products and spillage polluting our waters and lives. This site-specific installation will be executed with recycled materials combined to adapt to and redefine the main gallery at K Space Contemporary (KSC) into an ominous, seductive environment with not only constructions, but also lighting, sound, and kinetic features.

The artists, Day Wheeler and Jimmy Peña, have shared studio space for the past 14 years and have collaborated on many projects. Jimmy Pena is a self-taught artist with an impressive body of work surpassing many academically trained artists both conceptually and technically. Day possesses an MFA and teaches at a community college while continuing her studio work. While coming from different backgrounds, these artists work well together, bringing about collaborations that read as one voice.  

We are requesting funding for the creation, promotion, administrative and logistical support for this art exhibit. Many in our population are visual learners. "Prophecy" is a fresh approach for this area in addressing these concerns. With an island of plastic the size of Texas floating in the Pacific, animal injuries, fish kills, and overflowing landfills, man is leaving a negative footprint. This is a message that cries out to be heard. 

What We Need

We need $3,830 to fund this project.  We have already received $1830 from Texas Commission on the Arts (TCA), and seek to raise an additional $2000 with IndieGoGo.  TCA requires 1:1 matching funds, so you will also be helping us match our TCA grant.

The money will be spent as outlined below:

  • $1000 - Artists' Stipend & supply allowance.  Each artist will receive $500 towards supplies and time to create and install the exhibition. Artists may use their stipend as they feel best facilitates the creation of the exhibition.   
  • $1000 - Administrative costs include marketing via press releases to state and local media, KSC website, social media, and design for print materials.city, and gallery attendant. Additional cost free marketing will be achieved through the Corpus Christi Downtown Management District’s ArtWalk newsletter & website (http://www.artwalkcc.com/) and its publication DTown Delivers. 
  • $1500 - facility costs (rent/utilities).
  • $330 - Printing for 500 postcards, 200 brochures & vinyl for the title wall.  

Even if we do not reach our goal, the show will go on.  Budgets for Artists' Stipends and adminstrative costs will be cut evenly by a percentage determined by the amount raised.

Please see available funding levels and benefits to the right. 

The Impact

Because "Prophecy's" subject matter strikes a sensitive nerve in our area, we expect the exhibition to be well-received by the public and reviewed by our local newspaper, Corpus Christi Caller Times.  

Topics embraced by this installation include oil, water, green art, and ecological issues. Every kind of refuse washes onto the beaches in South Texas. Much comes from offshore oil-rigs, oil tankers passing through, and various other travelers on our waters, or visitors to our beaches. All imagery and construction in this installation will be made of recycled materials, with an emphasis on petroleum-based plastics. 

Prophecy's message is that it is time to remove manʼs negative impact on our waters.  We hope to make people aware that the world is facing a new apocalypse. The very balance of the ecological system is in obvious danger and the enemy is the human race. This type of alternative approach will interest a population where contemporary uncensored art is rare.

To enforce the message, KSC has invited the Texas Coastal Bend Chapter of the Surfrider Foundation to present information about the impact of pollution on the ocean and beaches during the opening reception.  

In addition, there will be a comment wall/community art piece where viewers participate by drawing or writing comments on refuse taken from a gathered pile from the beach. They will add their pieces to a viewer-made collage on the front gallery wall. Our goals is for visitors to become more aware of their own ecological footprint and perhaps, alter their garbage disposal behavior accordingly.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute money, you can still help by promoting this campaign and/or the exhibition:

1.  Share this Indiegogo campaign page. (Use the Indiegogo Share Tools)

2.  Email your friends the link to Prophecy's webpage and invite them to the opening reception: http://kspacecontemporary.org/exhibitions/prophecy-pena-wheeler/

3.  For regular updates and to share Prophecy info with friends, like K Space Contemporary on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/KSpaceContemporary

story:
Sweat, Blood and Silver Gelatin

 "The Female Fighter Project is portraiture series documenting female fighters around the globe through traditional, film-based photography. It all started in 2010 when I left the US for a year of international travel, visiting and training with some of the best female fighters from Rio de Janeiro to Tokyo."- Shawn Tamaribuchi

  • Shawn Tamaribuchi holds a BA in Photography / Digital Media from Scripps College, and has completed studies at the Glasgow School of Art. For the past ten years she has worked in the commercial and performing arts worlds. Her primary interests reside in the realm of digital-media and experimental art, and her performances and visual work has been seen locally, nationally, and internationally. She is commited to supporting the development of the martial arts through her art work and community programs for at risk youth and women. Currently, she holds the rank of brown belt in Brazilian Jiu Jitsu and is also an instructor and former professional MMA fighter.
  • The Solo Exhibition will be a month long show consisting of large format prints from images shot over the last three years. Featuring some of the world's bests international and local fighters, this is Shawn's first solo exhibition and she couldn't be prouder. It is scheduled to open Saturday, July 6th at Photobooth SF in San Francisco, CA. 
  • Preserving Tradition While Expanding the Arts is both the conceptual goal behind Shawn's art work as well as her personal philosphy behind her martial arts practice. She is asking for your help to offset the costs of producing this solo exhibition and remaining true to this mission.

 

My Old Muay Thai Coach Used to Say "Nothing For Free" (usually after he'd kick someone in the face)

Instead of taking on a mortgage, Shawn decided to invest a great deal of her personal savings into martial arts and documenting the people she met along the way. This solo exhibition offers her a chance to share the fruits of her labor, but she needs your help. Shawn is looking for help to partially cover the costs of the exhibition. 

  • Frames, Y U So Expensive? A lot of time and money go into producing a show. Film, development, scanning, editing, printing, mounting and framing all add up. Tack on the costs of promotion and promotional materials, It's no wonder we have this notion of the "Starving Artist". I am only asking for enough money to cover the basic cost of materials involved in the printing and framing of the work, $5,000. 
  • Loving You Is Easy because you are beautiful and generous! Aside from a great deal of my love, donors will be eligible for posters, fine art prints and promotional links on my website and social media feeds. Premium donors will receive a personalized video thank you and large format print of their choice.
  • It's the Journey Not the Destination. Although my hope is to exceed the target minimum of $5,000 for basic material costs, I am grateful for every cent that people can contribute to help offset some of the larger expenses and help me continue to document and pay tribute to the female fighter community.

 

POW! Right in the Kisser

 Let's do this!

  • Just the Beginning. Moving from the digital to physical space is a big leap for creative works which opens up the opportunity to expand the medium and the message. It allows the presense of female fighters to step outside the ring and into the art gallery generating further exposure for the athletes as well as the sport.
  • Is This Real Life? Yes and yes, because the Solo Exhibition has been scheduled, prints have been made, promotional postcards are in the works and you should totally come!

On Team Broke Too?

That's OK, because you can totally help me out in other ways by sharing this campaign with your friends, putting it on Facebook or Twitter, or perhaps writing a little blog about it.

  • LOOK!!! how convenient are those Share Buttons?
  • A Cat Video! That's right I made a video with my cat who also loves martial arts. It's on my web site so please share this and my indiegogo campaign with your friends, because the internet loves cats.

THANKS!

Shawn Tamaribuchi

story:
After the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in Dallas on November 22, 1963, Dallas was labeled by some as a "City of Hate." Now, fifty years later, 29 Pieces is partnering with over 60 community organizations to honor President Kennedy and to tell the world that love thrives in Dallas. The Dallas LOVE Project will engage 50,000 individuals in the creation of art on the theme of unconditional love. As a loving tribute to the memory of President Kennedy, the art will be displayed along the Kennedy motorcade route and throughout Dallas.

More than 60 local arts and community organizations are already engaged, including 29 Pieces, the Dallas Museum of Art, Matthews Southwest, Ronald McDonald House, South Dallas Cultural Center, Green Bandana Group, the Sixth Floor Museum, Keller ISD, United Nations Association, and many others.

50,000 people will participate in a variety of ways through sponsorship, creation of art, exhibition hosting, and partnership. Participants include students at Parish Episcopal, Uplift Education, Irma Rangel Young Women's Leadership School, Keller ISD, Maya Angelou High School for Pregnant and Parenting Teens, along with adults from Dallas County Jail, New Friends New Life, ArtLoveMagic, Artists Showplace and many other organizations.

WHAT: A collaborative public art initiative that celebrates the legacy of President John F. Kennedy and engages people of all ages and backgrounds to create and exhibit artwork about unconditional LOVE, inspired by quotes from great peacemakers, poets, writers, musicians, and artists.


WHY: To transform physical and mental walls across our city into galleries of LOVE and to respond to the perception from many years ago that Dallas is a "City of Hate."

WHEN: We will install art on the International Day of Peace, Saturday, September 21, 2013, and it will remain on exhibit through November 22nd, the 50th anniversary of JFK's assassination.

WHERE: A variety of venues throughout Dallas will exhibit artwork, with a focus along JFK's motorcade route from Dallas Love Field to Parkland Hospital. Art will be found on storefronts and inside buildings. There will be at least 10 major venues off the motorcade route, including Whole Foods, SouthSide on Lamar, St. Matthews Cathedral, the Dallas Public Library, Trinity Groves, and Lincoln Centre.

Who: Anyone! You do not need to be a professional artist to get involved or own a gallery to exhibit artwork. Schools, churches, businesses, museums, community arts groups, and more are all contributing.

HOW: There are many ways you can get involved! Find out more below or go to https://www.dallasloveproject.is/readyforyourinvolvement

Give: Continue to support this Indiegogo campaign at any level and help spread the LOVE! Your contribution will help pay for installation hardware and campaign expenses.
Participate: Create your own work of art to hang as part of the project. Volunteer to help install art at exhibit locations. (See above link for more information.)

Partner: Donors between $25 and $1,000 will come to a training session on how to lead a group to create LOVE art, organize a group to create LOVE art, and promote the project via social media. For more information please contact Karen Blessen at Karen@29Pieces.org.

Exhibit: Display 18" x 18" works of 2-D art at your organization or business from September 21st to November 22nd, 2013. For more information please contact Kara Hobbs at karah@dallasloveproject.is.

Sponsor: Support the project as an official sponsor and receive exclusive benefits. Email Darryl Ratcliff at darrylr@dallasloveproject.is or Liz Trosper at lizt@dallasloveproject.is for more information.


Thank you for taking the time to read and learn more about the Dallas LOVE Project! We hope that you decide to support this campaign, amazing project, and help transform Dallas into a City of LOVE!

story:
Andy’s career in the comic industry began at his first convention in 2006 where he exhibited his own fantasy art. Not long after his first convention, Andy began doing sketch cards sets for Marvel and DC Comics. Currently, he is working on his hit-list of comissioned sketch covers and sketch cards. Most recently, he is a cover artist for Zombies vs. Cheerleaders (March 2013). Andy has a steady fan base that keeps his hit-list busy with commissions.

 

The Give and Take - What We Need & What You Get

The Give:The cost of printing and shipping the sketchbook is $3,000. This is an initial run of 300 sketchbooks. The sketchbook is 110 pages and full-color. Included in the book are Andy’s personal fantasy art concept sketches, licensed sketch card sets, commissioned sketch covers, pin-ups and pencil sketches.  EVERY SKETCHBOOK WILL BE SIGNED.

Here’s the info on the book:

  • Full color soft cover
  • Full color gloss inside pages
  • Size: 7x10.5
  • Initial printing of 300

Shipping in the U.S. is included in perks. International shipping will be calculated and paid for by the pledger.

The Take: As a pledger to this project, you’ll get PERKS. See the levels of perks based on amount pledged.  Perks include-

  • 11x17 exclusive poster
  • pencil sketches (pick your character)
  • Signed Sketchbooks
  • Full color sketch cards (pick your character)
  • Full color sketches (pick your character)
  • Sketch covers (pick your character)
  • 11x17 FULL COLOR art (pick your character)

  • Signed regular and variant covers for Zombies vs Cheerleaders comic book

BE SURE TO CLICK ON 'GALLERY' TAB ABOVE TO CHECK OUT SOME SAMPLE PAGES FROM THE SKETCHBOOK. ALSO SEE A SHORT INTERVIEW DURING TUCSON COMIC-CON.

Ways You Can Help

Pledge, LIKE and SHARE.

Pledge to the project. If you’re unable to contribute monetarily you can still help spread the word.

LIKE Andy’s Facebook page  to stay informed and see the progress of his book.

SHARE it with your art-loving friends to help Andy gain exposure!

Pledge, LIKE and SHARE.

 

Click the Facebook "like" button! Help us spread the word about Andy’s sketchbook. Thank you!

 

 

All Characters in this sketchbook are owned by their respective entities.

All rights reserved. May not be reproduced in any way without written consent.
